title: Recommendation and Verification of a Personally Worn FM System
chief_complaint: I do not hear well with my current hearing aids, especially in group settings and noisy environments. I am constantly asking others to repeat, and I use captions on the television to follow the dialogue.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing loss first evident in high school.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; began investigating hearing aids approximately 15 years ago.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant bilateral tinnitus (louder in left ear); history of positional vertigo 1 year ago (resolved with Epley maneuver).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty in noise and groups; previous gain increases by audiologist did not improve communication; often reduces volume to prevent discomfort.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Improve communication in noisy environments and group settings.

history.present_illness: Patient reports progressive hearing loss since high school. Currently wears bilateral BTEs but reports poor benefit in noise.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia. Reports familial history of progressive hearing loss (father). History of BPPV (resolved).
history.prior_management: Has worn hearing aids for ~15 years. Current BTEs adjusted with increased gain previously, which caused discomfort without improving clarity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Mild SNHL (250-6000 Hz) sloping to moderate at 8000 Hz. Left ear: Mild SNHL (250-500 Hz) sloping to moderate (1000-8000 Hz).

numeric_results.RE_AC_Thresholds: 25-30 dB HL at low freqs sloping to ~55 dB HL at 8 kHz
numeric_results.LE_AC_Thresholds: 30-35 dB HL at low freqs sloping to ~60-65 dB HL at high freqs

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs mildly (Right) to moderately (Left) impaired. Word recognition scores are poor bilaterally (approx 50%) despite presentation at most intelligible levels.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral reflexes normal (500-4000 Hz). Contralateral reflexes elevated or absent. Decay testing could not be performed.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.key_findings: Frequency-specific loudness judgments performed to measure LDLs.

history.present_illness: Fitting of new amplification and FM system.
history.prior_management: Selected Phonak Exelia Art M BTEs and Phonak SmartLink+ transmitter with MyLink+ neckloop.

tests.name: Real-ear measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids programmed to NAL-NL1 targets. Measured REIG matched targets closely for 50, 65, and 80 dB SPL inputs. RESR90 curves corresponded appropriately to LDLs.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: FM Verification. Telecoil response verified (RSETS > 0 dB). FM transparency verified (EFMHA65 within 2 dB of EHA65).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss with flat to sloping configuration. Despite the degree of loss, word recognition scores are disproportionately poor (50-52% bilaterally), suggesting significant cochlear distortion or retrocochlear involvement (though reflexes/decay were inconclusive/absent). This explains the limited benefit from previous amplification strategies that focused solely on gain.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a mild-to-moderate hearing loss, but more importantly, your ability to understand words is significantly reduced (around 50%).
Because of this 'clarity' issue, simply making sounds louder with hearing aids won't fix the distortion—it's like turning up the volume on a fuzzy radio station.
To help you hear in noise, we are recommending an FM system. This acts like a direct wire from the speaker to your ears, bypassing the background noise.
You will need to have the person you want to hear speak into the FM microphone for it to work effectively.
notes_for_actor: Portray frustration with your current hearing aids—they make things loud, but you still can't understand words, especially in crowds.
You are motivated to try new technology (FM system) because you are socially withdrawing (e.g., dining out, playing cards).
You rely heavily on TV captions and are tired of asking people to repeat themselves.
